Description: Lower body fragment of East Greek pottery open vase, perhaps dinos. Inside glazed. Outside, from top: small part of upper frieze; key meander frieze between broad bands; frieze of goats browsing to left, part of two preserved (the hind part of the left goat, the head and shoulder of the right); in the field an outline rosette and dot rosettes; the haunch of the left goat and the shoulder of the right may have had added red.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Possibly School of the Oxford Oinochoe (Kardara pp.207-11). Compare Oxford G 119.12 (Kardara p.208, no.1; CVA Great Britain 9: pl.2 figs. 4-6; BSA 5 [1898-1899] pl.7 no.1) and Copenhagen 5607 (Kardara p.208 no.3 and p.209 fig.179) for dot rosette. For the filling ornament, the faces of goats, and the round hindquarters compare Berlin 2939 (Kardara p.208, no.4; JdI 1 [1886], 139); for the face of the goat compare Berlin 2944 (Kardara p.209, no.2; JdI 1 [1886], 140). The fragment also shows similarities, however, to vases in the Workshop of the Palermo Oinochoe (Kardara, pp.212-13); compare Boston 86.503 (Fairbanks, pl.34, 321.9; Kardara, p.213, no.10) for the faces, ears, and very thin rear legs. Compare Cambridge N33a (CVA Great Britain 11: pl.18 fig.19; Kardara, p.213 no.8 and p.212 fig.183) for the filling ornament.'
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 13, no. 40 pl. 9)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GG.918)
